content: Yes, life peers are taxpayers and they are subject to the same taxation laws as any other citizen. They do not receive a government salary for their work in the House of Lords, but they are entitled to a daily allowance when they attend House of Lords sittings or committee meetings. This allowance is intended to reimburse them for any expenses they incur while carrying out their duties, such as travel and accommodation costs. The amount of the daily allowance changes from time to time, and in recent years, it has been around £313 per sitting day. However, it's worth noting that many life peers do not claim the daily allowance, as they see their position as one of public service rather than a source of personal gain.
